The provider carries out tympanostomy with insertion of a ventilation tube in a single ear using an automated tube delivery system that also applies iontophoresis local anesthesia.

The provider transplants pancreatic beta islet cells from the patient’s own pancreas or a donor source to stimulate insulin production in a patient with diabetes. He infuses the cells into the portal vein of the liver through a tube that he inserts through a small skin incision in the abdomen. All imaging, imaging guidance, and radiological supervision and interpretation are included with this procedure.

The provider transplants pancreatic beta islet cells from the patient’s own pancreas or a donor source to stimulate insulin production in a patient with diabetes. He infuses the cells into the portal vein of the liver through a tube that he inserts using laparoscopic techniques. All imaging, imaging guidance, and radiological supervision and interpretation are included with this procedure.

Using an open (laparotomy) technique, the provider transplants pancreatic beta islet cells from the patient’s own pancreas or a donor source to stimulate insulin production in a patient with diabetes. He infuses the cells into the portal vein of the liver through a tube that he inserts through an incision in the abdomen. All imaging, imaging guidance, and radiological supervision and interpretation are included with this procedure.

The provider percutaneously implants or replaces an integrated neurostimulation system that stimulates the posterior tibial nerve to treat bladder dysfunction. The service may also include analysis, programming, and imaging guidance.

The provider revises or removes a percutaneously implanted integrated neurostimulation system that stimulates the posterior tibial nerve to treat bladder dysfunction. The service may also include analysis, programming, and imaging guidance.

A physician or other qualified healthcare professional performs electronic analysis and simple programming of one to three parameters of a previously implanted integrated neurostimulation system that stimulates the posterior tibial nerve to treat bladder dysfunction.

A physician or other qualified healthcare professional performs electronic analysis and complex programming of four or more parameters of a previously implanted integrated neurostimulation system that stimulates the posterior tibial nerve to treat bladder dysfunction.
A health and well–being coach meets face–to–face with an individual and performs and initial assessment.
A health and well–being coach meets face–to–face with an individual for a follow–up session lasting at least 30 minutes.
A health and well–being coach meets with a group of 2 or more individuals for a coaching session lasting at least 30 minutes.

The provider divides the humerus in two and inserts specially designed nails through the intramedullary canal of the two sections of humerus; the nail can be extended (distracted) using an external controller, which, over time, allows new bone to grow in the space between the two sections of the humerus and thus lengthens the humerus. Imaging, before and after alignment assessments and lengthening adjustments, and other device management are included with this procedure.

The provider measures the length of the patient’s urethra and inserts an intraurethral valve–pump for the first time to enable a female patient with impaired detrusor contractility to empty her bladder.
The provider removes an intraurethral valve–pump that enables a female patient with impaired detrusor contractility to empty her bladder.

The provider passes a proprietary hand–held imaging device over a wound, without touching the wound. Images displayed on the device’s monitor reveal the presence, amount, and location of bacteria in the wound.

The provider passes a proprietary hand–held imaging device over an additional wound or wounds at a different anatomic site from the first, without touching the wound. Images displayed on the device’s monitor reveal the presence, amount, and location of bacteria in the wound.

The provider performs percutaneous irreversible electroporation ablation using a minimally invasive technique that involves inserting a probe through the skin and other tissues to the area of the tumor and sending very short (microseconds) but strong nonthermal electrical pulses to punch holes in (permeabilize) the cells’ membranes to destroy the cells and prevent them from dividing; he treats one or more tumors per organ. Imaging guidance is included, so do not report it separately.

The provider performs irreversible electroporation ablation via an open procedure that involves inserting a probe to the area of the tumor and sending very short (microseconds) but strong nonthermal electrical pulses to punch holes in (permeabilize) the cells’ membranes to destroy the cells and prevent them from dividing; he treats one or more tumors per organ. Imaging guidance is included, so do not report it separately.

The provider places a proprietary sensor device on the patient’s skin and injects one dose of fluorescent pyrazine agent, and a  monitor displays the glomerular filtration rate, a measure of renal function.

The provider places a proprietary sensor device on the patient’s skin and injects a fluorescent pyrazine agent, and a  monitor displays the glomerular filtration rate, a measure of renal function. The provider administers more than one dose in a 24–hour period.
The ophthalmologist provides an optical coherence tomography (OCT) machine and has it set–up remotely for a  patient with retinal disease who is trained in the use of the machine.

Report this code for each 30–day period of remote surveillance center technical support for a minimum of 8 daily recordings of patient–initiated, remote optical coherence tomography imaging of the retina.
Report this code for each 30–day period when the provider reviews and interprets patient–initiated, remote optical coherence tomography retinal images and prepares a report.
The patient is provided and trained in the use of a multisensor cardiopulmonary “stethoscope” with a micro–controller which sends the results to a staffed 24–hour remote surveillance center.

The staffed 24–hour remote surveillance center reports analysis of data received and send the reports to the patient’s provider or another qualified healthcare professional in the provider’s office. This code may be reported only once in a 30–day period.

The provider performs magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) of at least three discs of the cervical (neck), thoracic (mid back), or lumbar (low back) with single–voxel acquisition of various biochemical markers per disc to assess structural integrity and diagnose discogenic pain.
Use this code to report transmission of biomarker data from magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) of the cervical (neck), thoracic (mid back), or lumbar (low back) for software analysis.

Use this code to report postprocessing for algorithmic analysis of biomarker data from magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) of the cervical (neck), thoracic (mid back), or lumbar (low back) for software analysis.
Use this code to report interpretation and report of biomarker data from magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) of the cervical (neck), thoracic (mid back), or lumbar (low back) for software analysis.

The provider inserts an interatrial septal shunt device between the left and right atrium via a percutaneous puncture over the femoral vein and advances it through a catheter to the upper chambers (atria) of the heart under imaging guidance. The provider may also perform left and right heart catheterization and intracardiac echocardiography.
The provider opens the chest wall pocket from the previous insertion and removes a substernal implantable defibrillator pulse generator, then puts a new pulse generator in the same pocket.

The provider administers an eye movement test that does not depend on spatial calibration to help identify whether a patient has suffered a brain injury or concussion. Interpretation and report are included with this code.

The provider inserts an artificial iris into a patient’s eye without removing the patient’s native lens or a previously placed intraocular lens and without insertion of an intraocular lens. If he removes the native iris, repairs it, or fixates it with sutures, the procedures are included with this code and should not be reported separately.

The provider inserts an artificial iris into a patient’s eye after removing the patient’s native lens and placement of an intraocular lens. If he removes the native iris, repairs it, or fixates it with sutures, the procedures are included with this code and should not be reported separately.

The provider inserts an artificial iris into a patient’s eye and inserts an intraocular lens or removes an existing intraocular lens and places another. If he removes the native iris, repairs it, or fixates it with sutures, the procedures are included with this code and should not be reported separately.

The provider performs a cystourethroscopy during which he incises the anterior prostate at the bladder neck (commissurotomy) and injects a drug or places a drug implant to help treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

The provider performing endovascular venous arterialization of the tibial or peroneal vein places one or more stents to allow blood to flow from a blocked artery to a vein. The procedure allows oxygenated blood to reach the target area, such as a foot, to treat chronic limb–threatening ischemia. The code includes vascular access, catheterization, and imaging guidance related to the procedure.

In a procedure also known as microinvasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS), the provider uses a laser to create holes in the eye’s trabecular meshwork. The procedure uses the ab interno approach, meaning inside the eye. Trabecular meshwork drains most of the aqueous humor from the eye, and creating holes assists this flow and lowers intraocular pressure in glaucoma patients.

In a procedure also known as microinvasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS), the provider uses a laser to create holes in the eye’s trabecular meshwork under endoscopic visualization. The procedure uses the ab interno approach, meaning inside the eye. Trabecular meshwork drains most of the aqueous humor from the eye, and creating holes assists this flow and lowers intraocular pressure in glaucoma patients.

This code represents the complete service of preparing and transmitting quantitative coronary computed tomographic angiography data, the computerized analysis of the data, review of the computerized analysis, and an interpretation and report. The service helps with assessing how severe a patient’s coronary disease is.

This code represents preparing and transmitting coronary computed tomographic angiography data for computerized quantification and characterization of coronary plaque. The service helps with assessing how severe a patient’s coronary disease is.

This code represents computerized analysis of coronary computed tomographic angiography data for quantification and characterization of coronary plaque. The service helps with assessing how severe a patient’s coronary disease is.

This code represents the work involved in reviewing computerized analysis of data from coronary computed tomographic angiography, reconciling discordant data, and completing an interpretation and report. The service helps with assessing how severe a patient’s coronary disease is.

The provider injects a cellular or tissue–based product under fluoroscopic guidance to treat a lumbar intervertebral disc. This code applies to the first level injected. The injection may occur on one side or both.

The provider injects a cellular or tissue–based product under fluoroscopic guidance to treat a lumbar intervertebral disc. This code applies to each additional level injected after the first level. The injection may occur on one side or both.

The provider injects a cellular or tissue–based product under computed tomography guidance to treat a lumbar intervertebral disc. This code applies to the first level injected. The injection may occur on one side or both.

The provider injects a cellular or tissue–based product under computed tomography guidance to treat a lumbar intervertebral disc. This code applies to each additional level injected after the first level. The injection may occur on one side or both.

The provider uses a hyperspectral imaging device that differentiates light absorption between oxygenated and deoxygenated hemoglobin, which may help with finding ischemic tissue. The provider interprets the data and completes a report. This code applies per extremity.

The provider performs a minimally invasive procedure that uses ultrasound to interrupt the pulmonary artery nerve supply. The code includes services required to complete the procedure such as imaging guidance and right heart catheterization.
The provider performs a computed tomography, or CT, examination of a single breast without using contrast material. The code includes, but does not require, 3D rendering.
The provider performs a computed tomography, or CT, examination of a single breast using contrast material. The code includes, but does not require, 3D rendering.

The provider performs a computed tomography, or CT, examination of a single breast first without using contrast material and then using contrast material. The code includes, but does not require, 3D rendering.
The provider performs a computed tomography, or CT, examination of both breasts without using contrast material. The code includes, but does not require, 3D rendering.
The provider performs a computed tomography, or CT, examination of both breasts using contrast material. The code includes, but does not require, 3D rendering.

The provider performs a computed tomography, or CT, examination of both breasts, first without using contrast material and then using contrast material. The code includes, but does not require, 3D rendering.
The provider uses a wireless, skin–mounted device to measure cerebrospinal fluid flow in a shunt to assess function. This code includes but does not require ultrasound guidance.

The provider examines the target tissue by exposing it to near–infrared light and analyzing the tissue’s absorption and emission of light. The provider acquires images, interprets the results, and completes a report. This code is specific to noncontact studies, meaning the device’s spectrometer sensors do not have direct contact with the skin. Use this code for the first or only anatomic site studied for a reason other than peripheral arterial disease screening.

The provider examines the target tissue by exposing it to near–infrared light and analyzing the tissue’s absorption and emission of light. The provider acquires images, interprets the results, and completes a report. This code is specific to noncontact studies, meaning the device’s spectrometer sensors do not have direct contact with the skin. Use this code for the first or only anatomic site studied for a reason other than peripheral arterial disease screening.
The provider uses a catheter navigated through the arteries to insert a restoration device in the heart’s left ventricle.
The provider implants a prosthetic tricuspid valve, or replaces one, using a catheter that he inserts through a small incision in the skin and which he threads through a vessel to the heart.

The provider uses a catheter and suction device navigated through the blood vessels to completely or partially remove a mass in the heart. The provider infuses aspirated blood back into the patient during the procedure.
The provider uses a catheter navigated through the blood vessels to insert a reduction device in the coronary sinus, the largest cardiac venous structure.
The provider inserts a gastrostomy tube (feeding tube) through the skin, using magnets to bring the stomach to the abdominal wall. She uses ultrasound guidance, including documentation and report.

The provider uses MRI to analyze tissue composition quantitatively. The service is limited to a single organ. The code represents acquiring, preparing, and transmitting data with an interpretation and report.
The provider uses MRI to analyze tissue composition quantitatively for multiple organs. The code represents acquiring, preparing, and transmitting data with an interpretation and report.

The provider uses MRI to analyze tissue composition quantitatively. The service is limited to a single organ. The code represents acquiring, preparing, and transmitting data with an interpretation and report. This add–on service occurs in conjunction with diagnostic MRI of the same anatomy.

The provider uses MRI to analyze tissue composition quantitatively for multiple organs. The code represents acquiring, preparing, and transmitting data with an interpretation and report. This add–on service occurs in conjunction with diagnostic MRI of the same anatomy.

In this service, a physician or other qualified healthcare professional performs a remote evaluation of programmed parameters of an implanted subcutaneous cardiac rhythm monitor system. Following his analysis, he reviews the results and prepares a report.

The provider performs capsule endoscopy for gastrointestinal tract imaging of the esophagus and stomach. He uses a magnet to control the movements of the capsule. He interprets the images and prepares a report.
The provider inserts an endoscope through the nose and down into the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum for diagnostic purposes. The provider may collect specimens by brushing or washing.

The provider inserts an endoscope through the nose and down into the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum for diagnostic purposes. The provider collects one or more biopsy specimens for diagnostic analysis.

The provider inserts an endoscope through the nose and down into the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum for diagnostic purposes. The provider inserts a tube or catheter in the lumen (inside space of a tube structure) of the gastrointestinal tract.

The provider uses laser to ablate (destroy) malignant prostate tissue using a transperineal approach and transrectal imaging guidance. The procedure also includes enhanced ultrasound imaging such as MR–fused images, which combine an MR image of the prostate with the real–time ultrasound.

The provider places screws in the anterior lumbar or thoracolumbar vertebrae and connects the screws using a flexible cable, typically to treat spinal curvature caused by scoliosis. This code applies to up to seven vertebral segments.

The provider places screws in the anterior lumbar or thoracolumbar vertebrae and connects the screws using a flexible cable, typically to treat spinal curvature caused by scoliosis. This code applies to eight or more vertebral segments.

The provider revises, replaces, or removes thoracolumbar or lumbar vertebral body tethering, which uses screws and a flexible cable, typically to treat spinal curvature caused by scoliosis. The provider may use thoracoscopy for the procedure.

The provider examines one or more skin lesions by applying an electrical signal through the lesion(s) using different frequencies and depths. The device uses an algorithm to classify the lesion and calculate a melanoma risk score based on the data.

In conjunction with a separately reportable service to restore blood flow in a blocked coronary artery or graft during an acute myocardial infarction (heart attack), the provider introduces a catheter in a coronary vessel to infuse supersaturated oxygen to reduce muscle damage. The code includes imaging used to complete the procedure.
The provider inserts an implant into the eye that delivers a drug at a controlled rate into the anterior segment (front–most region of the eye) to treat a condition such as glaucoma.

The provider removes a previously placed implant from the eye and then replaces it with a new implant. The implant delivers a drug at a controlled rate into the anterior segment (front–most region of the eye) to treat a condition such as glaucoma.

The provider takes patient measurements and calibrates the cooling cap to ensure proper fit and function for the patient, who will wear the cap during future chemotherapy sessions. The intent of cooling is to reduce hair loss.
The provider assists the patient with mechanical scalp cooling during a chemotherapy session by placing, monitoring use of, and removing the device, which involves a cap connected to a cooling unit.
The provider harvests a uterus from a deceased donor and preserves the uterus on ice and in cold preservation solution for transplantation into the recipient.
The provider uses an open approach to remove a uterus from a living donor and preserves the uterus on ice and in cold preservation solution for transplantation into the recipient.

The provider uses a laparoscopic approach or robotic surgery to harvest a uterus from a living donor and preserves the uterus on ice and in cold preservation solution for transplantation into the recipient.
The provider transplants a uterus previously harvested from a donor into a recipient.
The provider prepares a donor uterus from a cadaver or living donor for transplantation. Services may include dissecting and removing soft tissues and preparing uterine arteries and veins.
The provider prepares a donor uterus from a cadaver or living donor for transplantation by creating a venous anastomosis (connection).
The provider prepares a donor uterus from a cadaver or living donor for transplantation. This code applies to a single arterial anastomosis (connection).
The provider inserts one or more drainage devices into tissue in the anterior segment (front–most region) of the eye.?The device helps drain fluid from the eye, which may help reduce pressure.

The provider inserts a small probe into the vagina. The probe emits cryogen cooling and radiofrequency waves that heat tissue. The goal is to stimulate production of collagen, the tissue’s structural proteins, to treat urinary incontinence (unintentional passing of urine).
The provider ablates (destroys) one or more benign thyroid nodules using a laser. The approach is percutaneous (through the skin). The code includes imaging guidance.

The provider performs in–person device evaluation of a synchronized diaphragmatic stimulation system with programming before or after the patient undergoes surgery, another procedure, or testing. The provider’s service includes analysis, review, and report. The system is intended to help cardiac function in patients with heart failure.

The provider performs in–person interrogation device evaluation of a synchronized diaphragmatic stimulation system with connection, recording, and disconnection. The provider’s service includes analysis, review, and report. The system is intended to help cardiac function in patients with heart failure.

The provider uses a laparoscopic approach to insert or replace a synchronized diaphragmatic stimulation system, including one or more leads and a pulse generator. The system is intended to help cardiac function in patients with heart failure.

The provider uses a laparoscopic approach to insert or replace the first lead of a synchronized diaphragmatic stimulation system. They also connect the lead to an existing pulse generator. The system is intended to help cardiac function in patients with heart failure.

At the same session as placement of an initial lead, the provider uses a laparoscopic approach to insert or replace another lead of a synchronized diaphragmatic stimulation system. They also connect the lead to an existing pulse generator. The system is intended to help cardiac function in patients with heart failure.

The provider uses a laparoscopic approach to reposition the first lead of a synchronized diaphragmatic stimulation system. They also connect the lead to an existing pulse generator. The system is intended to help cardiac function in patients with heart failure.

At the same session as repositioning of an initial lead, the provider uses a laparoscopic approach to reposition another lead of a synchronized diaphragmatic stimulation system. They also connect the lead to an existing pulse generator. The system is intended to help cardiac function in patients with heart failure.

The provider uses a laparoscopic approach to remove one or more leads of a synchronized diaphragmatic stimulation system. The system is intended to help cardiac function in patients with heart failure.

The provider inserts or replaces the pulse generator of a synchronized diaphragmatic stimulation system. The provider also connects the pulse generator to one or more leads that are already in place. The system is intended to help cardiac function in patients with heart failure.

The provider relocates the pulse generator of a synchronized diaphragmatic stimulation system. The provider also connects the pulse generator to leads that are already in place. The system is intended to help cardiac function in patients with heart failure.

The provider opens a subcutaneous (under the skin) pocket to remove the pulse generator of a synchronized diaphragmatic stimulation system. The system is intended to help cardiac function in patients with heart failure.

The provider performs in–person programming device evaluation of a synchronized diaphragmatic stimulation system, making repeated adjustments to find the optimal programmed settings. The provider’s service includes analysis, review, and report. The system is intended to help cardiac function in patients with heart failure.
The provider uses a special device to deliver ultrasound energy into the body to destroy cancerous liver tissue. The provider monitors the treatment using image guidance.
The provider performs initial services for an online digital amblyopia (lazy eye) treatment program, including device supply, education, and the first session.

The physician or other qualified healthcare professional assesses patient performance and program data from an online digital amblyopia (lazy eye) treatment program and provides a report. Report this code once per calendar month.
The provider uses ultrasound imaging data and software to analyze tissue quantitatively, and then provides an interpretation and report.

In conjunction with a primary diagnostic ultrasound service of the same anatomy, the provider uses ultrasound imaging data and software to analyze tissue quantitatively and then provides an interpretation and report.

Automated analysis of an existing computed tomography (CT) dataset checks for vertebral fractures. The analysis also may assess bone density. The code includes data preparation, interpretation, and report.
The provider uses an ultrafiltration machine to remove excess fluid from a patient, such as a patient with heart failure.

The provider uses cameras and analytical software to collect and quantify full–body human kinematics and kinetics, which relate to motion. The system does no use markers on the patient’s body. The service also includes a report.

The provider obtains 3D imaging and reconstruction of a breast or axillary (armpit) lymph node tissue specimen during an operation, such as mastectomy. The system is capable of automatic specimen reorientation. The service includes interpretation and report.

The provider uses body surface–activation mapping, such as by multiple–lead electrocardiography, to optimize electrical synchrony of a biventricular pacing or biventricular pacing–defibrillator system at the time of implant or replacement. The goal is to restore electrical synchrony in dyssynchronous heart ventricles, which pump out of sync because of erratic electrical impulses.

The provider uses body surface–activation mapping, such as by multiple–lead electrocardiography, to optimize electrical synchrony of a biventricular pacing or biventricular pacing–defibrillator system at the time of a follow–up interrogation or programming device evaluation. The goal is to restore electrical synchrony in dyssynchronous heart ventricles, which pump out of sync because of erratic electrical impulses.
The provider uses MRI to analyze tissue composition quantitatively for multiple organs. The code represents acquiring, preparing, and transmitting data with an interpretation and report.

The provider uses MRI to analyze tissue composition quantitatively for multiple organs. The code represents acquiring, preparing, and transmitting data with an interpretation and report. This add–on service occurs in conjunction with diagnostic MRI of the same anatomy.
The provider injects medication in the posterior chamber of the eye, typically for therapeutic purposes.
The provider uses a fluorescent dye, special imaging device, and analysis software to assess a suspicious mole for tissue changes and cell abnormalities. This code applies to the first lesion.

The provider uses a fluorescent dye, special imaging device, and analysis software to assess a suspicious mole for tissue changes and cell abnormalities. This code applies to each additional lesion after the first.
The provider performs initial services for a remote amblyopia (lazy eye) treatment program that uses an eye–tracking device. The service includes device supply, initial setup, and patient education.
A surveillance center provides technical support for a remote amblyopia (lazy eye) treatment program that uses an eye–tracking device.
A physician or other qualified healthcare provider completes an interpretation and report for a patient’s remote amblyopia (lazy eye) treatment program that uses an eye–tracking device.
The provider injects bone–substitute material into a subchondral bone defect. Imaging guidance and arthroscopy to visualize the joint are included.
The provider prepares the cancer immunotherapy and performs an initial intradermal injection.
After an initial injection, the provider performs another intradermal cancer immunotherapy injection.

The provider uses software to process data from noncoronary computerized tomography angiography (CTA) for arterial plaque analysis. This complete–service code covers data preparation, assessment of atherosclerotic plaque stability, and data review with interpretation and report.
The provider prepares data from noncoronary computerized tomography angiography (CTA) and transmits it for arterial plaque analysis.
The provider uses software to process data from noncoronary computerized tomography angiography (CTA) for assessment of atherosclerotic plaque stability.

The provider reviews data and provides an interpretation and report assessing atherosclerotic plaque stability based on software processing of noncoronary computerized tomography angiography (CTA) data.

The provider uses laser to ablate (destroy) benign tissue of an enlarged prostate. The approach is transperineal, going through the area between the scrotum and anus. This code includes imaging guidance and applies when the prostate volume is less than 50 mL.
The provider uses a device that records heart sounds, analyzes them, and generates a coronary artery disease risk score.

The provider harvests fat cells from the patient and submits the cells to a variety of processes that result in a certain concentration and dilution of regenerative cells. In a separately reportable procedure, the provider will inject the cells into the same patient for treatment of a partial thickness rotator cuff tear.

Under ultrasound guidance, the provider injects specially prepared cells (derived from tissue previously harvested from the patient) into the supraspinatus tendon, which is part of the rotator cuff muscles of the shoulder. The procedure is unilateral (performed on one side).

The provider replaces a lumbar spine joint, including bilateral facetectomy (facet joint removal), laminectomy (removing the back part of the vertebrae), and radical discectomy (removal of disc material). The code includes imaging guidance.
The provider places a stimulation device and electrodes in the external ear area for percutaneous electrical nerve field stimulation of the cranial nerves.
The provider uses imaging data and software for quantitative CT tissue characterization and then provides an interpretation and report.

The provider uses imaging data and software for quantitative CT tissue characterization and then provides an interpretation and report. This add–on code is appropriate when there is concurrent CT exam of at least one anatomic structure included in the diagnostic imaging dataset acquired at the same time.

The provider uses magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography data and software to assess the biliary system quantitatively. The code includes preparation and transmission of data as well as interpretation and report by the provider.

The provider uses magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography data and software to assess the biliary system quantitatively. The code includes preparation and transmission of data as well as interpretation and report by the provider. Use this add–on code in conjunction with a primary code for diagnostic MRI of the same anatomy.
The provider implants a vestibular device on one side of the patient’s head. The device may help restore lost vestibular function, which may assist with balance and related issues.
The provider removes an implanted vestibular device on one side of the patient’s head. The device may have been implanted to help restore lost vestibular function (balance and related issues).

The provider removes a vestibular device and then implants another on one side of the patient’s head. The device may help restore lost vestibular function, which may assist with balance and related issues.

The provider performs diagnostic analysis and initial programming of a vestibular device implanted on one side of the patient’s head. The device may help restore lost vestibular function, which may assist with balance and related issues.

The provider performs diagnostic analysis and subsequent programming of a vestibular device on one side of the patient’s head. The device may help restore lost vestibular function, which may assist with balance and related issues.
Under optical coherence tomography guidance, the provider uses a laser to remove tissue, opening a canal to improve outflow of fluids in the eye.

The provider uses artificial intelligence (AI) technology to analyze a patient’s facial features, such as to help identify rare genetic syndromes. The provider completes a report based on interpretation of the data.
The provider administers an immunotherapy agent into a muscle and administers electrical pulses to improve uptake of the immunotherapy.

Following an order by a physician or other qualified healthcare professional, a provider supplies the necessary equipment and technical support for remote real–time, motion capture–based neurorehabilitative therapy. This code is reportable once per 30 days.

Following an order by a physician or other qualified healthcare professional, a provider performs treatment management services related to remote real–time, motion capture–based neurorehabilitative therapy. This code is reportable once per calendar month.
At the same session as a primary craniotomy, the provider prepares the tumor cavity and places a radiation therapy applicator for intraoperative radiation therapy.
The provider inserts a catheter into the patient’s rectum and performs colonic lavage (washing out) with water to induce defecation.
The provider implants a tissue graft from a nonhuman species into the surface of a joint.
The provider uses data from a previously performed MRI to complete treatment planning for malignant prostate tissue ablation (destruction) that uses a magnetic field to heat injected nanoparticles.
The provider performs malignant prostate tissue ablation (destruction) that uses a magnetic field to heat injected nanoparticles.
The provider performs the initial setup of a remote autonomous algorithm–based recommendation system for insulin dose calculation and titration. The provider also educates the patient on proper use.

The provider provides software and is responsible for collection, transmission, and storage of data for a remote autonomous algorithm–based recommendation system for insulin dose calculation and titration. This code is reportable each 30 days.

As an add–on to a primary SPECT myocardial (heart muscle) perfusion imaging study, the provider performs absolute quantitation of myocardial blood flow (AQMBF). The test is performed under stress and possibly at rest.

The provider assesses bone strength and risk of fracture using computer analysis known as finite element analysis. The service also includes classifying any vertebral fractures and assessing overall fracture risk.
The provider uses a hand or wrist X–ray taken for another purpose to assess bone strength and fracture risk. The method is digital X–ray radiogrammetry–bone mineral density (DXR–BMD) analysis.
The provider takes and uses a single–view digital X–ray and uses it to assess bone strength and fracture risk. The method is digital X–ray radiogrammetry–bone mineral density (DXR–BMD) analysis.
The provider uses an open approach to implant a bioprosthetic valve in the large femoral vein of the thigh.
The provider uses imaging data and electrical data (like ECG) to localize and map the site of an arrhythmia to prepare for separately reportable radiation ablation of the site.
The provider converts previously performed localization and mapping for an arrhythmia (abnormal heartbeat) into a treatment plan for separately reportable radiation ablation of the site.
The provider treats an arrhythmia (irregular heartbeat) using radiation to destroy the originating site.
The provider injects stem cells into soft tissue around a fistula near the anus.
The provider uses a hand or wrist X–ray taken for another purpose to assess bone strength and fracture risk. The method is digital X–ray radiogrammetry–bone mineral density (DXR–BMD) analysis.
The provider takes and uses a single–view digital X–ray and uses it to assess bone strength and fracture risk. The method is digital X–ray radiogrammetry–bone mineral density (DXR–BMD) analysis.

Concurrent with performing a separately reportable electrocardiogram (ECG), the provider uses algorithms enhanced by artificial intelligence to assess the patient for cardiac issues.
Using data from a previously performed electrocardiogram (ECG), the provider uses algorithms enhanced by artificial intelligence to assess the patient for cardiac issues.

The provider locates the peripheral nerve for treatment and defines the appropriate magnetic stimulation amplitude. The provider may use nerve conduction to confirm the nerve location. The provider uses noninvasive magnetic stimulation of a peripheral nerve. This code applies to the first or only nerve treated.

The provider locates the peripheral nerve for treatment and defines the appropriate magnetic stimulation amplitude. The provider may use nerve conduction to confirm the nerve location. The provider uses noninvasive magnetic stimulation of a peripheral nerve. This code applies to each additional nerve treated after the first at a single encounter.
In addition to a base therapy service, the provider uses virtual reality (VR) technology to assist the therapy. This code represents the practice expense for the VR software.

A qualified healthcare professional (QHP) performing a separate diagnostic or therapeutic procedure also provides virtual reality (VR) procedural dissociation services to increase patient comfort. This code represents the first 15 minutes of VR intraservice time for a patient who is at least 5 years of age.

A qualified healthcare professional (QHP) performing a separate diagnostic or therapeutic procedure also provides virtual reality (VR) procedural dissociation services to increase patient comfort. This add–on code represents each additional 15 minutes of VR intraservice time for a patient who is at least 5 years of age.

A qualified healthcare professional (QHP) provides virtual reality (VR) procedural dissociation services to increase patient comfort while a separate QHP performs a diagnostic or therapeutic procedure. This code represents the first 15 minutes of VR intraservice time for a patient who is at least 5 years of age.

A qualified healthcare professional (QHP) provides virtual reality (VR) procedural dissociation services to increase patient comfort while a separate QHP performs a diagnostic or therapeutic procedure.  This add–on code represents each additional 15 minutes of VR intraservice time for a patient who is at least 5 years of age.
The provider places devices on the patient’s neck and head. The devices are part of a cooling system that decreases the blood’s temperature before it enters the brain.
In conjunction with an epidural injection, the provider uses a device that detects pressure changes to help identify and confirm the epidural space in real time.

The provider performs in–person measurement and recording of dynamic joint motion and muscle function. The service requires multiple inertial measurement unit (IMU) with concurrent surface mechanomyography (sMMG) sensors. A cloud–based processing platform processes the data from multiple sensors and produces an automated report.

The provider places sensors on the patient’s abdomen to measure the electrical activity of the patient’s gastrointestinal tract, from the stomach to the colon. The provider completes an interpretation and report.
The provider uses a rectal enema to transplant fecal bacteria from a healthy donor into a recipient.
The provider inserts a specialized catheter through a bronchoscope and completes a circumferential radiofrequency ablation in the main bronchus of each lung to destroy pulmonary nerves.
The provider inserts a specialized catheter through a bronchoscope and completes a circumferential radiofrequency ablation in the main bronchus of one lung to destroy pulmonary nerves.

The provider performs setup, calibration, and patient education for the use of a transcutaneous auricular neurostimulation device. The device may have a noninvasive earpiece that is wired to a unit to deliver electrical stimulation, such as to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve and trigeminal nerve.
The provider percutaneously inserts or replaces an electrode array with an integrated neurostimulator system for the spine. The provider may use imaging guidance for the procedure.
The provider revises or removes an electrode array with an integrated neurostimulator for the spine.
The provider percutaneously inserts or replaces a sacral electrode array with an integrated neurostimulator system. The provider may use imaging guidance for the procedure.
The provider revises or removes a sacral electrode array with an integrated neurostimulator for the spine.

A physician or other qualified healthcare professional performs electronic analysis and simple programming of one to three parameters of a previously implanted integrated neurostimulation system that stimulates the spinal cord or sacral nerve.

A physician or other qualified healthcare professional performs electronic analysis and complex programming of four or more parameters of a previously implanted integrated neurostimulation system that stimulates the spinal cord or sacral nerve.

The provider revises, replaces, or removes thoracolumbar or lumbar vertebral body tethering, which uses screws and a flexible cable, typically to treat spinal curvature caused by scoliosis. The provider may use thoracoscopy for the procedure.
In conjunction with a primary gait–training service, the provider uses motor–cognitive, semi–immersive virtual reality. Each unit of this code represents 15 minutes.
The provider applies silver diamine fluoride 38 percent.

The provider performs a minimally invasive procedure that uses heat to interrupt the pulmonary artery nerve supply. The code includes services required to complete the procedure such as imaging guidance and right heart catheterization.

The provider submits the patient’s clinical and existing molecular, laboratory, or pathology result data for assessment. An algorithmic program will create a report, ranking available cancer drug therapies based on the patient’s cancer biomarkers.
The provider uses a catheter to implant a complete dual–chamber leadless pacemaker system in the heart. The provider may use imaging guidance for the procedure.
The provider uses a catheter to implant the right atrial pacemaker component of a dual–chamber leadless pacemaker system in the heart. The provider may use imaging guidance for the procedure.
The provider uses a catheter to implant the right ventricular pacemaker component of a dual–chamber leadless pacemaker system in the heart. The provider may use imaging guidance for the procedure.
The provider uses a catheter to remove a complete dual–chamber leadless pacemaker system in the heart. The provider may use imaging guidance for the procedure.
The provider uses a catheter to remove the right atrial component of a complete dual–chamber leadless pacemaker system in the heart. The provider may use imaging guidance for the procedure.
The provider uses a catheter to remove the right ventricular component of a complete dual–chamber leadless pacemaker system in the heart. The provider may use imaging guidance for the procedure.
The provider uses a catheter to remove and replace a complete dual–chamber leadless pacemaker system in the heart. The provider may use imaging guidance for the procedure.

The provider uses a catheter to remove and replace the right atrial component of a complete dual–chamber leadless pacemaker system in the heart. The provider may use imaging guidance for the procedure.

The provider uses a catheter to remove and replace the right ventricular component of a complete dual–chamber leadless pacemaker system in the heart. The provider may use imaging guidance for the procedure.

The provider performs an in–person evaluation and then repeatedly tests and adjusts the programmed settings of an implanted dual–chamber leadless pacemaker system for the heart. The service includes analysis, review of the results, and a report.
The provider uses a percutaneous femoral vein approach to implant prosthetic valves in the vena cava using a catheter.
The provider uses an open femoral vein approach to implant prosthetic valves in the vena cava using a catheter.

The provider uses software that analyzes the patient’s lung ventilation by combining separately captured cinefluorograph images and previously acquired CT images. The code includes data preparation and transmission, quantification of pulmonary tissue ventilation, data review, interpretation, and report.

The provider uses software that analyzes the patient’s lung ventilation by combining separately captured cinefluorograph images and CT images taken for this analysis. The code includes data preparation and transmission, quantification of pulmonary tissue ventilation, data review, interpretation, and report.
